Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research and Development of Algorithms in a Software Factory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objectives of Montana State University's (MSU) Computer Science (CS) Department REU project are 1) to expose undergraduate students to real-world, innovative and interdisciplinary algorithms research founded in modern software engineering techniques; 2) to encourage more undergraduates to continue their academic careers and seek graduate degrees in computer science and related disciplines; 3) to develop research skills and improve communication and collaborative skills; and 4) to foster collaboration and entrepreneurship in the development of prototype software through our innovative Software Factory environment. The REU program will aim to broaden impact and participation by recruiting high-quality undergraduate students from regional tribal colleges, students from small colleges with limited resources, as well as women engineering students to increase the gender and cultural diversity of students. The REU projects encourage students to take a systems-level perspective in solving problems from an ever-growing number of diverse commercial, educational and environmental domains. This REU will increase student awareness of cultural diversity and bolster academic confidence and interest among underrepresented groups to aid in retention and advancement, as well as preparing students in real world development environments. The program will leverage highly successful MSU campus-wide and College of Engineering programs already in place to recruit and retain underrepresented students from Montana tribal colleges.

By using a realistic software development environment - the Software Factory, the PIs will heighten undergraduate student participation in innovative research of algorithm development. Project topics have been carefully selected by each mentor to make sure they include a significant development component. It seeks to increase the number and diversity of students entering graduate programs and research careers in computer science and related fields. The program will target a variety of topics in interdisciplinary research aligned with every mentor's area of expertise. The students will acquire key general research skills, learn how to design algorithms and develop and use tools to tackle complex problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Montana State Universitys (MSU) Gianforte School of Computing carried out a three-year NSF REU site for 24 undergraduate over a three year period.The program attracted high quality undergraduate students from across the country to participate in the development and research of algorithms in a Software Factory.

The program addressed the nations need for developing a diverse group of computer science researchers and professionals capable of not only research, but also the development of algorithms in a modern software engineering setting. With the rise of interdisciplinary research the PIs recognized the need to educate young scientists in transferring their knowledge in scientific algorithms into well designed software prototypes that adhered to sound software engineering techniques. This is imperative because scientists today are reliant on software that can accurately reproduce results. By enhancing the research experience in interdisciplinary algorithms with sound software engineering and development techniques, we equipped young scientists with the necessary tools to be effective in the workplace (academic and commercial).

The Software Factory is a dedicated physical space intended to emulate a real software development environment. The concept of a Software Factory is well established and proven. During the 2014-2015 academic year, the CS Department at MSU successfully launched its Software Factory in collaboration with the University of Helsinki, Finland home of the original Software Factory.

Students participated in many diverse domains to develop algorithms including:

  • Tools for Reducing the Technical Debt of Systems
  • Tools for Computing Genomic Distances with Gene Duplications
  • Software tools for Pan-Genomics
  • Sustainable Software Package for Topological Data Analysis
  • Understanding trustworthiness in mobile social networks
  • Biomedical Natural Language Processing Tool for Extracting Protein-Function Relations from Literature
  • Risk-based Vehicle Health Management

The projects alloed REU participants a large choice of projects and domains in which to experiment with new algorithmic techniques while being mentored by experts in the field. Students were immediately immersed in graduate labs and collaborated with other students to produce posters and 5 publications.

Our numbers for diversity are shown comparing our prior REU to this one. It is important to note that this REU only supported 8 students per year (as opposed to 10 per year in the prior program). We made improvements in recruiting Asian American as well as Latinx students while maintaining a 50% target of female students.
